meanings.definition: To portray or represent as diabolic or evil.
meanings.sent1: In the movie, the villain tried to diabolize the hero by spreading lies about him.
meanings.sent2: The tabloids often diabolize celebrities to sell more copies.
meanings.sent3: The gossip columnist loved to diabolize the local baker, claiming he used cursed ingredients.
meanings.sent4: Her angry words seemed to diabolize the air around her, making everyone uncomfortable.
meanings.sent5: The artist's dark paintings diabolized the beauty of nature, creating a haunting effect.

meanings.definition: To speak evil of; slander; defame.
meanings.sent1: Some people enjoy diabolizing others to make themselves feel superior.
meanings.sent2: It is not right to diabolize someone just because they have a different opinion.
meanings.sent3: The jealous neighbor would often diabolize the old lady who lived next door.
meanings.sent4: Her words seemed to diabolize his reputation, turning friends against him.
meanings.sent5: The politician's opponents tried to diabolize his character with false accusations.

meanings.definition: To act as a devil; play the devil.
meanings.sent1: During the play, the actor had to diabolize the character of the devil with convincing evil laughter.
meanings.sent2: The children loved to diabolize during Halloween, pretending to be spooky creatures.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kitten seemed to diabolize the household, causing chaos wherever it went.
meanings.sent4: His mischievous grin made him look like he was ready to diabolize the whole party.
meanings.sent5: The comedian's performance made him diabolize as a playful devil, entertaining the audience.
